Authors: Lin Zhao, Ying Zhang, Wei He
Title:
Two Novel Neofusicoccum Species Causing Stem Blight and
Dieback of Blueberries in China
Keywords:
berries, fungal diseases, optimal temperature, pathogen
distribution, tree fruits
Abstract:
Blueberries (Vaccinium spp.) have been considered to be a
superfood because of their health benefits. Stem blight or dieback of
blueberry plants has been frequently observed in commercial plantations,
with incidences between 15 and 30% being observed in China. The causal
agent of blueberry stem blight and dieback were surveyed at four
commercial blueberry plantations in China during 2017 and 2018.
Twenty-eight isolates of Neofusicoccum were obtained from 75 diseased
and dead stem samples of blueberry plants. Two novel species, N.
vaccinii and N. highlandense, were identified based on morphological
characteristics and nucleotide DNA sequence analysis of concatenated
internal transcribed spacer, translation elongation factor-1α gene and
β-tubulin gene sequences. Tests of Kochs postulates indicated that both
N. vaccinii and N. highlandense were pathogenic toward blueberry plants.
Mycelial growth of Neofusicoccum spp. occurred at temperatures ranging
from 5 to 35 °C, while the optimal temperature for the mycelial growth
of both N. vaccinii and N. highlandense was 30 °C.
